text: Locrian hi everyone
Anthony Fantana here the Internet's been
a bit of a and it's time for a review of
the new low korean album return to
annihilation these guys were a Chicago
band a three-piece and for about ten
years now they've been toiling under the
radar making all kinds of experimental
rock music turning out numerous records
sometimes a few within the span of one
year and the music on these records is
usually a twisted cauldron of black
metal post Rock drone noise dark ambient
music as well the band really emphasizes
texture sound dynamics and intensity to
over everything else you know things
like a strong melody or accessibility
and the band makes this pretty
mountainous music on their new album as
well on what at times feels like a
shoestring budget there is definitely a
slightly low fight quality to the music
on this album there's a lot of ambient
noise room noise surrounding some of the
instruments like the drums the recording
is a little rickety it's a little loose
a little noisy but the sounds are still
very heavy rich and vivid it's just a
recording that's got a some character to
it I would say you know it's got a lot
of blemishes on I suppose but the
performances are there the sounds are
there now similar to artists like Tim
Hecker or Boards of Canada for example
the music that Locrian makes is
incredibly visual its cinematic it's
very thematic there are actually some
pretty strong themes on this album I
would say of Apocalypse vastness
desolation and they embrace these
feelings with some really raw drums some
tattered distorted keyboards some heavy
bass and some very bouncy echo drenched
guitars even though the elements that
look Korean works with on this record
are very simple they do create some very
strong moods with them using a lot of
repetition throughout these tracks to
really create a place in in my mind that
I can sort of freely wander through as
I'm listening to it
some of the tracks on this record it's
not like the songs really have a a
beginning point and an end point per se
it's not like they have a strong
progression it's like they just are
they're static they stay there's a lot
of stillness in these tracks like the
track exiting the Hall of vapor and
light which has these distorted
keyboards some wandering guitars in a
very patient beat it is a very
repetitive song but it feels like the
more the band repeats these ideas over
and over and over the more real and and
the more vivid this soundscape they're
creating becomes the more I feel as if
I'm in it it's almost as if I kind of
want that repetition I'm looking for it
because what Locrian is creating in this
song it's so evocative however sometimes
the repetition sort of works against
locrians favor because the sounds that
they're working with or the music that
they're playing it's it's really not
that evocative it's not that moving like
these stumbling guitar leads throughout
the track to moons which I'm really sort
of cold toward or the song of visitation
from the wrath of heaven which has this
huge monstrous ending which breaks in
suddenly reminds me of something Mogwai
used to do on their older stuff and I
love the finish the instrumentation is
really thick it's heavy there's so much
texture flying at me at once it's
overwhelming but the span of six minutes
in between this point and the intro
where the band is really repeating on
this primal drumbeat these weird reverse
melodies that are cycling over and over
and over I I guess I'm not then thrall
dwith this interlude the end is amazing
but the journey on the way there is just
not that stellar I just wish it were a
little more engaging like the second
half of this LP actually like the title
track on here which is actually pretty
multifaceted it starts off with these
just rich twangy guitars that feel like
I'm hearing a bit of a desert hymnal or
something going on especially with the
vocals in the background there's a
droney interlude a post-rock like build
up and then this hellish black metal
inspired downward spiral at the finish
it's a pretty intense frigging ride and
the 15 minute closer is is actually my
favorite moment on here maybe with the
acoustic guitar in the heavy
bassy piano keys right at the start and
the song evolved into moments of noise
of drone black metal and I love how the
band keeps their sound palette really
similar from track to track to track and
even from genre shift to genre shift
making all of these various influences
come together and feel sort of cohesive
as if they're meant to be together
anyway this closing track as it just
trudges on it becomes this deafeningly
apocalyptic dirge it is it is the
perfect closure for this thing and
really encapsulate s' the cover art that
we have going on here the lone shopping
cart empty parking lot fog the Locrian
rights on the South melodically or chord
wise is definitely not as interesting as
their sound play and it's not as
interesting as their very wide mix of
influences unfortunately but still it
didn't make this album any less
enjoyable for me what did you think of
it did you love it hate it why what do
you think I should review next and
that's it I want to give a shout out to
chainsaws which you might hear in the
background John Dan Kottke the hip hop
heads reddit Jaime's world and Chris H
oh and also the straw I forgot that in
last video but if you don't understand
that this is my review and this is my
opinion here is a straw
only the strong subscribe all mistakes
were intentional Anthony Fantana Locrian
forever
